I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the Country Programming Mission in December 2007, the Government of the 
People’s Republic of China (PRC) requested that the Asian Development Bank (ADB) provide 
advisory technical assistance (TA) for a policy study on transport efficiency through logistics 
development.  The  Fact-Finding  Mission  visited  Beijing  in  August  2008,  during  which  an 
agreement was reached with the Government on the TA’s impact, outcome, methodology, key 
activities, cost estimates, financing plan, and implementation arrangements, as well as the 
mission’s observations. The TA design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. This TA has 
also been included in the ADB nonlending program for the PRC for 2008.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The PRC’s continuous economic growth, since the start of its economic reforms in 1978, 
has been accompanied by a rapid increase in demand for transport and logistics.2 Freight traffic 
grew from 983 billion ton-kilometers (km) in 1978 to over 10 trillion ton-km in 2007, an annual 
growth rate of 8.4%. Of this, road freight grew by 13.7% annually, coastal and inland waterway 
freight by 10.3% annually, and railway freight by 5.3% annually.3 The total value of the PRC’s 
logistics4 industry grew by an average of 21% from 2000 to 2007 and is anticipated to continue 
growing  rapidly.  The  Government  is  allocating  greater  resources  to  expand  the  transport 
infrastructure  in  order  to  remove  bottlenecks  and  to  improve  accessibility.  However, 
infrastructure investment cannot keep pace with the transport demand, which has put increasing 
pressure  on  the  transport  system.  Developing  an  efficient  logistics  industry  is  becoming 
increasingly  important  for  sustainable  economic  growth,  trade  performance,  environmental 
protection, and poverty reduction in the PRC. 
 
3.  The PRC faces challenges to efficient logistics development. The ratio of total logistics 
cost5 to gross domestic product represents the efficiency of logistics operation in the economy. 
i.e.,  the lower the ratio, the better the efficiency. Despite the PRC’s ratio declining from 21.2% in 
1991 to 18.4% in 2007, it is still double that of developed countries. Moreover, the share of 
logistics cost of finished products in the PRC is much higher than the normal range of 10%–25% 
for  an  efficient  operation—particularly  in  inland  regions—further  reflecting  a  needed 
improvement in its logistics development.  
 
4.  Transport  is  an  integral  element  of  the  logistics  supply  chain.  In  Organisation  for 
Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) countries, transport cost accounts for a 
quarter of all logistics cost. In the PRC, although the transport system is rapidly improving, 
transport costs still accounted for 54% of the total logistics cost as of 2007—the greatest 
amount among all cost components. Tolls are a major cost for transport users and contribute to 
oversized and overweight trucks and the diversion of through-traffic to less appropriate routes. 
                                                 
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 15 September 2008. 
2  Logistics is defined as the process of planning, implementing, and controlling the efficient and effective flow and 
storage of goods, services, and related information from the point of origin to point of consumption to meet 
customer requirements. The goal of logistics is to have the right thing at the right place at the right time for the right 
cost. 
3  The modal split for freight tonnage carried was 72% for roads, 14% for railways, 12% for coastal and inland 
waterways, and 2% for pipelines and civil aviation. The modal split for freight ton-km was 63% for coastal and 
inland waterways, 24% for railways, 11% for roads, and 2% for pipelines and civil aviation. 
4  The total logistics value represents the total value of final products delivered to end-users after utilizing logistics 
services.  
5  The logistics cost includes costs associated with transport; warehousing and storage; management; packaging, 
processing, and distribution; loss and damage; and interest incurred through carrying out the logistics activities.

2   
In addition, higher empty backhaul rates, dated material handling and warehousing, higher 
damage rates, and inefficient distribution of goods are other transport cost items higher in the 
PRC than in developed countries. Furthermore, moving goods between provinces can be a 
challenge due to local protectionism. 
 
5.  Inefficient  logistics  also  result  in  increased  energy  consumption  and  air  pollution 
concerns; unsurprisingly, the PRC is the world’s fastest growing oil consumer. From 2000 to 
2005, the transport sector’s consumption of petroleum increased from 25% to 30% of total use 
and is projected to reach 50% in 2020. To cope with emerging environmental issues, policies 
and measures to increase transport energy efficiency are highly desirable, such as raising the 
quality of transport services, raising vehicle standards (with greater use of containers and larger, 
multi-axle  trucks),  and  fostering  integrated  logistics  service  provider  development.  Further 
developing inland waterway transport can also lower environmental impact in terms of high 
energy efficiency per ton-km. Most importantly, the focus should gradually shift away from the 
construction of new infrastructure to more effective utilization of existing infrastructure. 
 
6.  The major challenges of the logistics industry include the following.  
 
(i)  There is a lack of coordination among different government departments and 
organizations. As government agencies are structured along modal lines, they 
manage intermodal issues mainly from their own perspectives. This results in an 
array  of  fragmented  legal  and  regulatory  structures,  inconsistent  technology 
standards, and lack of interoperability between different transport modes. 
 
(ii)  Due  to  imbalanced  infrastructure,  transport  bottlenecks  and  gaps  in  the 
interconnectivity between modes still exist, particular in central and western PRC 
and rural regions. 
 
(iii)  Trucking and barge companies are fragmented and consist of many small owner-
operators,6 lacking efficiency in terms of economies of scale. No single company 
commands  more  than  2%  of  the  market  or  provides  nationwide  intermodal 
transport services. Lack of standardized container-carrying wagons or container 
trucks  has  led  to  additional  costs  in  loading  and  reloading,  especially  when 
multimodal transport is used, resulting in low truck productivity levels.7 In addition, 
logistics services’ poor credibility and integrity acts as another barrier to efficient 
logistics. 
 
(iv)  Inadequate  human  resources,  many  of  whom  lack  logistics  management 
knowledge and skills, hamper the industry’s further growth.  
 
7.  Optimizing transport systems through advanced logistics solutions is a proven strategy 
in the developed countries. Third-party logistics (3PLs), a new and developing industry in the 
PRC,  offer  integrated  services  to  meet  companies’  supply  chain  needs.  At  present,  most 
domestic manufacturing and commercial enterprises manage their own logistics operations, with 
only 15% outsourcing their logistics functions. As a result, 3PLs’ share of the logistics market is 
significantly lower compared to that in the developed countries. Fostering the development of 
3PLs will put pressure on small logistics operators to improve services, simulate the growth of 
modern technology, reduce logistics cost, and improve quality of transport services. 
                                                 
6  Most barge and trucking firms have one to three vehicles and self-powered small vessels. 
7  The average annual output per truck in Canada is 12 times more than the output in the PRC.

3 
8.  As a key element of efficient logistics, multimodal integration will enable users to choose 
the most cost-effective transport mode for specific types of freight, lower average transport 
costs, and raise energy efficiency. The key characteristic of multimodal transport is the carriage 
of  goods  by  two  or  more  transport  modes,  under  one  contract,  using  one  consignment 
document and one responsible party for the entire carriage. Presently, each transport mode 
tends  to  be  developed,  managed,  and  regulated  in  isolation,  and  missing  infrastructure 
elements within a mode and between modes prevent seamless multimodal supply chains. More 
attention also needs to be paid to modal interfaces such as inland terminals, container stations, 
and cargo clearance facilities. Balanced multimodal investment and development will create a 
system that exploits the comparative economic advantages of different modes to benefit the 
transport system and the population. Furthermore, establishment of a uniform regulatory and 
legal regime is crucial for successful multimodal transport. 
 
9.  Inland  waterways  must  also  become  a  policy  focus.  In  addition  to  lowering 
environmental impact (para. 5), most PRC water routes run from west to east, linking inland 
sources of minerals and agriculture products to the major eastern seaboard markets. Therefore, 
inland  waterways  are  well  positioned  to  serve  the  Government’s  policy  to  develop  inland 
provinces.  
 
10.  While most logistics services are provided by the private sector, governments have a 
significant role to play in creating the appropriate policy framework conditions by (i) integrating 
logistics in the transport policy agenda; (ii) adopting a multimodal approach; (iii) improving the 
effective and efficient use of existing infrastructure through closer intergovernment coordination, 
competition policy, pricing reform, and public–private partnership; (iv) promoting the use of 
information technology through education and human resources development; (v) raising safety 
standards; and (vi) strengthening monitoring mechanisms. Further, government involvement is 
critical in addressing information asymmetries (i.e., correcting situations where one or more 
parties  in  a  transaction  possess  information  not  known  to  other  parties);  and  negative 
externalities (e.g., making a polluter pay through taxes and promoting a modal shift to more 
environmentally friendly modes, especially in urban areas and congested corridors). 
 
11.  Recognizing  that  the  policy  focus  had  been  unimodal  rather  than  multimodal,  the 
Government created the Ministry of Transport (MOT) in April 2008, which incorporates the 
former Ministry of Communications. Aviation, maritime concerns, roads, postal services, and 
urban public transport are among the new MOT’s functions. Its major responsibilities include: 
(i) designing the layouts, policies, and standards of the development of roads, waterways, and 
civil aviation; and (ii) establishing a convenient, smooth, efficient, safe, and integrated transport 
system in the PRC. MOT therefore seeks to learn from international experiences and best 
practices in transport and logistics management. 
 
12.  The Government has given high priority to logistics development and included it in the 
11th Five-Year Plan (2006–2010). Therefore, consistent with the plan and aligned with ADB’s 
country partnership strategy for the PRC,8 this TA aims to assist the Government in developing 
a  framework  strategy,  policies,  action  plans,  and  implementation  mechanisms  for  efficient 
logistics development. Further, the TA supports ADB’s strategy by (i) facilitating inclusive growth 
and  balanced  development  by  promoting  an  integrated  and  coordinated  transport  system, 
(ii) improving  resource  efficiency  and  environmental  sustainability  by  promoting  sustainable 
mobility, and (iii) promoting public–private partnerships in multimodal transport and logistics 
services. Inclusive growth and balanced development in the PRC depends on improving its

transport sector in order to lower transport and logistics costs for both industrial and consumer 
goods.  Transport  and  logistics  cost  savings  also  help  to  raise  output,  jobs,  and  incomes. 
Efficient and affordable freight transport diversifies rural economies, and both urban and rural 
producers and consumers benefit from better logistics services. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
13.  The TA’s impact will be an efficient, safe, and environmentally friendly transport logistics 
system in the PRC. The TA’s outcome will include a policy framework, measures, action plans, 
and operational guidelines that can be adopted by MOT and local governments in the PRC. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
14.  The  TA  will  focus  on:  (i)  undertaking  a  detailed  assessment  of  the  PRC’s  current 
logistics  development,  focusing  on  the  economic,  legal,  organizational,  institutional,  and 
regulatory conditions of intermodal transport services; (ii) identifying key issues to develop in the 
logistics  industry;  (iii)  learning  from  international  experiences  and  good  practices  from 
developed  countries  where  multimodal  transport  and  logistics  are  efficiently  managed; 
(iv) recommending specific changes to regulatory frameworks to achieve the transport sector’s 
desired goals; (v) preparing recommendations, including comprehensive best practices, policy 
notes on policy frameworks, measures, action plans by particular agencies, and implementation 
mechanisms  with  a  realistic  indicative  timetable  for  implementation;  (vi)  carrying  out  case 
studies in three provinces (east, west, and central) to analyze approaches to implementing 
recommendations;  (vii)  developing  operating  guidelines  to  assist  local  governments  in 
implementing  recommended  policies  and  measures;  and  (viii)  undertaking  workshops  for 
consultation with stakeholders and disseminating findings.  
 
15.  International experts and national consultants will be engaged for the TA. The TA will be 
undertaken in close consultation with concerned central and provincial governments and will 
take into consideration all previous studies carried out by the Government, ADB, and other 
multilateral agencies, as well as best international practices. The TA will involve fieldwork; 
gathering  international  experiences;  analytical  research;  and  stakeholder  consultations  with 
national  and  provincial  governments,  the  private  sector, international  and  national  logistics 
providers, customers, and international development partners. Capacity-building support will be 
provided  through  international  and  national  training  programs  to  implement  TA  outputs. 
Workshops—at inception, interim, and draft final report stages of TA implementation—will be 
organized to discuss and review the TA’s findings, and a seminar will be organized at the final 
report stage to disseminate these findings.  
 
16.  The TA will include case studies from the three selected provinces to identify barriers to 
logistics development that can be overcome through sound policy measures and other means.9 
The case studies will also pilot test TA recommendations and operating guidelines. 
 
                                                 
9  The final selection of the three case study provinces will be made during TA contract negotiations. Provinces that 
are willing to provide their own counterpart staff and resources for field studies will be considered.

5 
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The TA is estimated to cost $625,000 equivalent. The Government has requested that 
ADB finance $500,000 equivalent on a grant basis through ADB’s TA funding program. MOT will 
provide the remaining $125,000 equivalent in counterpart staff, office space, furniture, and other 
support services. The cost estimates are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  MOT will be the Executing Agency for the TA. It will assign appropriate counterpart staff 
to assist the consultants and form a project steering committee, which will be chaired by a 
deputy  director  general  of  the  Comprehensive  Planning  Department.  It  will  include  senior 
officials from MOT’s Comprehensive Planning Department, Waterway Transport Department, 
Highway  Transport  Development,  Institutional  Reform  and  Legal  Affairs  Department,  and 
Finance Department; relevant officers of ministries and agencies concerned. 
 
19.  The TA will be implemented from May 2009 to December 2010. Consulting services 
totaling 39 person-months (9 international and 30 national) will be required. The terms of 
reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. 
 
20.  The consultants will be engaged by ADB through a national firm associated with an 
international firm, in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as 
amended from time to time) on the basis of the quality of the proposal (90%) and the cost (10%) 
of  the  services  to  be  provided  using  simplified  technical  proposal  procedures.  The  90:10 
weighting is considered appropriate because the TA is a complex multidisciplinary assignment 
that requires innovation and creativity, and the quality of the consulting services will have a 
significant impact on the ensuing policies and guidelines. Disbursement will be undertaken in 
line with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2008, as amended from time to 
time). All reports by the consultants will be prepared in English and translated into Chinese. The 
consultants will maintain close working relations with ADB and MOT and will regularly discuss 
progress and findings. Tripartite meetings involving ADB, the consultants, and MOT will be held 
to provide guidance to the consultants and to review their reports.  
 
21.  MOT will provide a suitably furnished office with utilities and telecommunication access, 
materials, maps, data, and documents required by the TA, and will cover the cost of utilities for 
the consultants, counterpart professional staff, and support staff. TA equipment will be procured 
by the consultants in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007) and transferred to 
MOT upon completion of the TA. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for Transport Efficiency through Logistics 
Development Policy Study, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  General 
1.  The  consultants  will  perform  their  tasks  in  close  consultation  with  the  Ministry  of 
Transportation  (MOT)  and  other  responsible  central,  provincial,  and  local  government 
departments and agencies to ensure full acceptance of the outcome of the technical assistance 
(TA). The TA is estimated to require 39 person-months of professional input (9 person-months 
international,  30  person-months  national).  The  consultants  should  demonstrate  extensive 
consulting skills and experiences in the field of: (i) policy and institutional (5 person-months 
international, 5 person-months national); (ii) transport system and logistics operations (2 person-
month international, 10 person-months national); (iii) transport logistics economics and policy 
analysis  (2  person-months  international,  5  person-months  national);  (iv)  transport  law  and 
economic  regulations  (5  person-months  national);  (v) freight  information  and  technology 
(5 person-months national). 
 
2.  The consultants should propose their own staffing schedule in the technical proposal, 
must demonstrate the range of skills and experience required and a well planned and balanced 
deployment  of  time  from  each  team  member  to  meet  the  TA  objectives.  The  assignment 
requires a strong commitment from a team Leader, deputy team leader, and the core team. 
 
3.  The team leader/national logistics specialist will, in addition to technical functions, have 
overall responsibility for the effective and timely implementation of the TA. This consultant will 
foster close coordination between international and national consultants and coordinate with the 
Executing  Agency  (EA),  other  related  government  agencies,  the  Asian  Development  Bank 
(ADB), and other international organizations doing related work in partnership with ADB. The 
team leader will periodically report progress to the EA and ADB, and submit high-quality reports 
to both. 
 
4.  The deputy team leader/international policy and institutional specialist will, in addition to 
technical  functions,  work  closely  with  the  team  leader  to  establish  and  maintain  good 
coordination with the EA, other related government agencies, ADB, and other international 
organizations. This consultant will assist the team leader in reporting progress periodically and 
submitting high-quality reports to the EA and ADB, and will be responsible for ensuring the high 
quality of the English versions of the inception report, interim report, and draft final report. 
 
B.  Scope of Work 
5.  The TA will be implemented from May 2009 to December 2010. These work will include, 
but are not limited to, the following tasks:. 
 
6.  Part 1: Multimodal Transport Regulatory Review 
(i)  Identify, review, and assess the legislative and regulatory frameworks applied 
and their implementation mechanisms of specific transport modes (including road 
freight haulage, inland waterway freight transport, coastal shipping, air freight, 
railway, and multimodal) and logistics industry in the PRC, Japan, South Korea, 
Germany, and USA. Compare and analyze the objectives, features, performance, 
and experience of each of them. 
(ii)  Examine  the  specific  logistics  requirements  of  (a)  rice,  (b)  perishables, 
(c) parcels, (d) full container-loads by road, and (e) full container-loads by mixed

10  Appendix 3 
modes. Examine the documentary requirements and legal framework specific to 
each  type  of  supply  chain.  Use  real  examples  to  illustrate  specific  logistics 
requirements.  
(iii)  Analyze and assess the impacts of economic regulations including industry entry, 
capacity,  ownership,  management,  competition,  pricing,  operating  costs, 
investment, flexibility and innovation. Use real examples to illustrate impacts. 
(iv)  Discuss the objectives and operation status of regulations with regulatory bodies. 
Identify areas where changes to the regulatory framework will benefit multimodal 
transport and logistics development and private sector participation. 
(v)  Conduct a stakeholder workshop to ensure a common understanding of the 
regulatory framework and operating environment for transport and logistics in the 
PRC. Discuss the advantages and disadvantages of some of the alternative 
regulatory models implemented in other countries. 
(vi)  Identify policy changes and actions that need to be taken to improve transport 
services  to  inland  regions  and  establish  improved  conditions  for  market 
development. 
(vii)  Make specific recommendations for changes to the regulatory frameworks to 
achieve efficient, safe, and environment-friendly transport logistics system in the 
PRC. For each recommendation, identify the specific legislative and regulatory 
instruments which will need to be amended or replaced, and prepare drafts of the 
recommended legislative instruments required or amendments to them. 
(viii)  Identify necessary policy decisions and consultative requirements which will be 
necessary  to  implement  the  recommendations.  Provide  a  realistic  indicative 
timetable for implementation by MOT. 
 
7.  Part 2: Multimodal Transport Logistics 
(i)  Review  and  analyze  relevant  studies,  reports,  data,  and  related  information 
including lessons learned from past work on transport logistics. Review logistics 
industry performance. Generate a list of data and information sources. 
(ii)  Undertake  a  comprehensive  review  of  the  existing  transport  logistics 
performance.  Indicate  and  analyze  the  present  status  and  future  trends  in 
logistics market development in the PRC. Recommend a list of performance 
indicators to benchmark the performance, and examine how to collect them. 
(iii)  Identify the main shortcomings of transport logistics. Analyze the non-physical 
barriers (economic and administration, etc.) that prevent the transport logistics 
markets from working (“bottlenecks exercise”). 
(iv)  Analyze and compare the logistics system in the PRC, Japan, South Korea, 
Germany,  and  USA.  Review  international  best  practices  including  principles, 
strategies, measures,  institutional  structure,  standard,  information  technology, 
and  monitoring  and  mechanism  in  each  of  those  countries.  Identify  the 
comparative advantages of the system in each country through a strengths and 
weakness analysis that will include reviewing the features, performance, and 
experiences. 
(v)  Undertake comprehensive case studies in three provinces to obtain reliable first-
hand information from logistics service providers, forwarders, and users. Identify 
user’s requirements and key factors influencing user decisions in intermodal 
transport (e.g., interoperability of services, and liability provisions for loss and 
damage). Conduct a stakeholder workshop in the field and discuss the findings. 
(vi)  Compare  and  analyze  the  international  and  national  best  experiences  on 
planning, methodology, construction, and operations of logistics centers, and

Appendix 3  11 
inland  container  depot  (ICD)  including  public  and  private  sector  roles  in the 
process. Investigate optimal design criteria for logistics centers and ICD taking 
into account the production and consumption patterns in the captive area of the 
terminals.  
(vii)  Analyze the existing problems of the 3PL operators, including their access to the 
market, their links with other operators and forwarders. Summarize international 
and national best practices of logistics development including the development of 
3PL  logistics  firms  and  measures  to  encourage  information  technology 
development. 
(viii)  Research on the role of transport operators in providing an integrated, intermodal 
service 3PLs to the transport users. Investigate the advantages of cooperation 
among different operators in understanding the possible combinations of value 
added services (for instance, real time information, integrated pricing system, 
increased speed, etc.) and on how they should be organized. 
(ix)  Get insight into the potential market for intermodal transport, based on demand 
analyses on macro and micro levels. Analysis of opportunities and benefits for 
change from unimodal to multimodal approach.   
(x)  Identify deficiencies in the transport development plans in terms of multimodal 
transport efficiency.  
(xi)  Identify the role that central and local government can play in further supporting 
the logistics business development to ensure fair competition and provide an 
enabling environment for private sector.  
(xii)  Review the establishment of an integrated liability concept covering the whole 
intermodal transport chain and its actors. 
(xiii)  Review the efficiency and effectiveness of the on-line training program for truck 
owners and drivers provided by the International Road Transport Union. 
(xiv)  Make specific policy recommendations to remove obstacles by technical and 
other means in a more efficient way. 
 
8.  Part 3: Transport Logistics Efficiency 
 
1.  Transportation Cost 
 
(i)  Consult industry associations and a sample road freight operators, barge and 
shipping companies (national public and private, and international) to investigate: 
(a) the existing structure and levels of transportation costs and charges such as 
fuel, toll, and other charges; (b) the existing structure and levels of taxes imposed 
on selected freight transport operators including business tax, value added tax, 
and income tax; (c) revenues; and (d) estimate the level of profit margins. 
(ii)  Analyze  and  compare  the  average  transport  cost  and  tariff  structure  with 
developed countries. Recommend a preferred system and structure of taxes, 
fees and toll charges, taking account of the needs of inland regions. 
 
2.  Transport Management and Efficiency 
 
(i)  Analyze  main  shortcomings  of  the  freight  transport  management  including 
specific  technologies  and  information  technology  development,  and  identify 
causes of the problems. 
(ii)  Review international best practices, regulations, enforcement procedures and 
incentives on eliminating empty backhaul trips. Recommend policy measures

12  Appendix 3 
that eliminate empty backhaul problem and control vehicle emissions to increase 
fuel efficiency. 
(iii)  Review international best practices, regulations, enforcement procedures and 
incentives on reducing overloading and excessive working hours of drivers (such 
as the use of tachographs). 
(iv)  Review  international  experience  and  make  specific  recommendations  to 
strengthen MOT’s role in freight transport efficiency, safety and vehicle emissions. 
(v)  Review international experience; identify measure and incentives for usage of 
more  economically  efficient  fleet  (such  as  use  of  large  capacity  trucks  and 
increase swap trailers). 
(vi)  Make  recommendations  to  enhance  the  credibility  and  integrity  of  logistics 
providers through application of information technologies.  
 
9.  Part 4: Recommendations 
(i)  On the basis of the findings and analyses under the above three parts. Prepare 
recommendations to 
•  Identify the non-physical barriers that prevent the transport logistics markets from 
working.  Compare  it  with  international  best  practice  and  prepare 
recommendations for strategic approach. 
•  Prepare  comprehensive  best  practices  policy  notes  on  policy  framework, 
measures, action plans, and implementation mechanisms to improve transport 
logistics. 
•  Prepare recommendations on legal and regulatory changes (including advices on 
amendments to the existing legislation or regulations, or propose new legislation 
regulations if necessary). 
•  Recommend an improved institutional structure in MOT and local government 
level to facilitate multimodal transport logistics. 
•  Prepare recommendations on improving planning, management, and operation 
of logistics centers and ICD. 
•  Prepare recommendations on further improving multimodal transport strategies 
and plans. 
 
(ii)  On the basis of the findings and analyses under the above three parts. Prepare 
policy measures, action plans and implementation mechanisms to:  
 
•  reduce freight transport cost and actions needed to be taken by each transport 
sector (particularly for road and inland waterways); 
•  reduce freight transport cost and increase efficiency; 
•  facilitate entry and development of 3PL firms; 
•  raise safety standards including preventing excessive working hours of drivers 
and overloading; 
•  promote environment-friendly logistics services; 
•  facilitate  private  sector  participation  in  logistics  centers  and  inland  container 
depots; 
•  increase backloading and raise fuel efficiency; 
•  improve transport logistics system in economically disadvantaged remote areas; 
and

Appendix 3  13 
 
(iii)  Develop operational guidelines to assist local governments in implementing the 
recommendations  and  action  plans.  Propose  a  pilot  application  to  test  and 
demonstrate the benefits of the recommendations. 
C.  Reporting. The consultants will submit the following reports to ADB and MOC:  
(i)  An Inception Report within 3 months of the starting date including an outline of 
the final report, a working paper on current transport laws and regulations, draft 
international experiences, and the objectives and methodology to be applied for 
field surveys. 
 
(ii)  A one day workshop with government officials and private sector participants to 
ensure that key issues of the transport and logistics regulatory and operating 
environments are clearly understood and to discuss alternative solutions. 
 
(iii)  An Interim Report within 6 months of the starting date summarizing all work 
performed, the consultants’ findings and recommendations and presenting the 
draft policy recommendations. 
 
(iv)  A one day workshop in a case study province to present the interim report to 
policy makers at the central and provincial level, private participants to facilitate 
the exchange of ideas and gather comments on the proposed recommendations. 
 
(v)  A Draft Final Report. A comprehensive draft report on all aspects of the study, 
including an Executive Summary) within 9 months of the starting date. 
 
(vi)  A one day workshop with government officials and private sector participants on 
the results of the Study and a possible timetable for implementation, using the 
Draft Final Report as key resource. 
 
(vii)  A Final  Report. A comprehensive report on all aspects of the study taking 
account of the results and feedback from the stakeholders’ Workshop within 
12 months of the starting date. The comments from ADB and MOT will be issued 
no later than 6 weeks after the issuance of the DFR. 
 
(viii)  Arranging and conducting a national seminar to be led by MOT to present and 
discuss the findings and recommendations of the study. Two weeks’ input time is 
allowed for disseminate the results of the TA. Four weeks’ input time is allowed 
for this publication of the results of the TA. 
 
(ix)  All reports will be written in English and translated into Chinese. Five copies of 
each report (in English) will be submitted to ADB and five copies (in both Chinese 
and English) to the MOT. The reports should address all aspects of the terms of 
reference to the level of detail appropriate for the given stage of the TA. The 
consultants will present key findings in the workshop and symposium. Members 
of the project steering committee, representatives of the Ministry of Finance, 
National Development and Reform Commission, local governments in the pilot 
provinces, industry associations, local communities, and ADB staff will participate 
in the workshops and the tripartite meetings.
